abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>CYP2C8 is responsible for the metabolism of 5% of clinically prescribed drugs, including antimalarials, anti-cancer and anti-inflammatory drugs. Genetic variability is an important factor that influences CYP2C8 activity and modulates the pharmacokinetics, efficacy and safety of its substrates.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>We profiled the genetic landscape of <jats:italic>CYP2C8</jats:italic> variability using data from 96 original studies and data repositories that included a total of 33,185 unrelated participants across 44 countries and 43 ethnic groups. The reduced function allele <jats:italic>CYP2C8*2</jats:italic> was most common in West and Central Africa with frequencies of 16–36.9%, whereas it was rare in Europe and Asia (< 2%). In contrast, <jats:italic>CYP2C8*3</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>CYP2C8*4</jats:italic> were common throughout Europe and the Americas (6.9–19.8% for <jats:italic>*3</jats:italic> and 2.3–7.5% for <jats:italic>*4</jats:italic>), but rare in African and East Asian populations. Importantly, we observe pronounced differences (> 2.3-fold) between neighboring countries and even between geographically overlapping populations. Overall, we found that 20–60% of individuals in Africa and Europe carry at least one <jats:italic>CYP2C8</jats:italic> allele associated with reduced metabolism and increased adverse event risk of the anti-malarial amodiaquine. Furthermore, up to 60% of individuals of West African ancestry harbored variants that reduced the clearance of pioglitazone, repaglinide, paclitaxel and ibuprofen. In contrast, reduced function alleles are only found in < 2% of East Asian and 8.3–12.8% of South and West Asian individuals.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Combined, the presented analyses mapped the genetic and inferred functional variability of <jats:italic>CYP2C8</jats:italic> with high ethnogeographic resolution. These results can serve as a valuable resource for <jats:italic>CYP2C8</jats:italic> allele frequencies and distribution estimates of CYP2C8 phenotypes that could help identify populations at risk upon treatment with CYP2C8 substrates. The high variability between ethnic groups incentivizes high-resolution pharmacogenetic profiling to guide precision medicine and maximize its socioeconomic benefits, particularly for understudied populations with distinct genetic profiles.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: V.M.L. is co-founder, CEO and shareholder of HepaPredict AB. Y.Z. and V.M.L. are co-founders and shareholders of Shanghai Hepo Biotechnology Ltd. The other authors declare no competing interests.

title: Meta-analysis of the global distribution of clinically relevant CYP2C8 alleles and their inferred functional consequences
